Theoretical calculations at the revPBE0-D3(PCM)/def2-TZVP level were performed to investigate the mechanism of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) on the FeN4-doped NCMs (graphene, single-walled (6,6)-armchair and (12,0)-zigzag carbon nanotubes) as catalysts. The effect of the support and relative orientation of FeN4 fragment in the catalyst structure on the ORR activity and stability of the differently adsorbed successive intermediates (O2*, HO2*, O*, HO*, H2O2*, H2O*) is discussed. Special attention is given to the possible poisoning effect of CO. The relative catalytic activity of the metal center and the adjacent C2 site of the carbon support are analyzed depending on the structure of the support. The metal catalytic center on the armchair nanotube and graphene supports is prone to deactivation by poisoning with CO, whereas in the zigzag nanotube supported catalyst the metal center is tolerant to CO. The four-electron mechanism of ORR is shown to be preferable over the two-electron mechanism in both acidic and alkaline media, both on the metal and C2 centers. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction DFT Mechanism Iron, Nitrogen doping Carbons Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The development of efficient methods of transformation of chemical energy to electric energy is an urgent and challenging task in many fields aimed at reducing the negative impact of carbon dioxide emission from fossil fuels and solving the problem of clean energy production. One promising approach is the controlled electrochemical reduction of oxygen occurring in fuel cells and metal-air batteries [1,2]. The sluggish kinetics of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode requires the use of catalysts [3,4]. The most effective and widely used commercial catalyst towards ORR is Pt/C exhibiting very low overpotential. However, Pt/C catalysts suffer from such shortcomings as high price and low stability with respect to active oxygen species (hydrogen peroxide, singlet oxygen, superoxide and hydroxyl radicals), carbon monooxide or methanol in the near-cathode space [5] leading to aggregation of active centers under reductive conditions and, hence, unavoidable poisoning of the catalyst [6,7]. This, in turn, requires large catalyst loadings, that reduce the effectiveness of its commercial application. Hence, the search for inexpensive catalysts for the ORR resulted in the discovery of the catalytic activity of non-noble metal doped heteroatom co-doped nanocarbon materials, NCMs [8].The ORR catalysts of this type exhibits excellent mechanical and electrochemical properties and demonstrate good stability under harsh conditions of the target reaction, and are easy to obtain, for example, by pyrolysis of the transition metal macrocycles (such as phthalocyanines (Pcs) or porphyrins (PPs) in the presence of nanocarbon materials (NCM; graphene (Gr), carbon nanotubes (CNTs), etc.) [4,9–11]. Among the transition metal-doped nanocarbon materials, a high ORR activity was found for the nitrogen-anchored Fe [12–14], Co [15,16], Cu [17–20], Sn [21,22], and bimetallic catalysts on their basis [23,24], as well as for Si [25–27]. Nowadays, the Fe,N-doped NCMs are considered as one of the most promising non-precious electrocatalyst candidates for the ORR in both acidic and alkaline media [12,13]. The progress in the synthesis and investigation of the catalytic properties of various Fe,N-doped NCMs toward ORR is summarized in two reviews devoted exclusively to this pair of dopants [12,28]. A thorough analysis of the literature allowed Liu et al. [12] to make a number of important conclusions and to determine further vector of investigations in the field of rational design of the ORR catalysts [29–32]. Among them are: (i) the choosing a proper carbon support is vital for synthesizing a high-performance ORR catalyst [33]; (ii) dispersing iron(II) phthalocyanine on different types of carbon nanotubes, FePc/MWCNT catalysts [34] exhibit the best ORR performance in alkaline electrolyte close to the state-of-the-art Pt/C reference catalyst, while in acidic conditions an even higher half-wave potential (E 1/2) of up to 0.93 V (vs. RHE) than that of the Pt/C with E 1/2 value of up to 0.88 V can be achieved [35,36]; (iii) the optimal catalyst with a trace Fe content (down to 0.05 wt.%) can demonstrate a superior high performance compared with commercial Pt/C in alkaline ORR conditions [37]; (iv) according to quantum chemical calculations, ORR activity is attributed to the metal center surrounded by four or five pyridinic nitrogen atoms in the composition of Fe–N4/C and Fe–N5/C catalysts [14,38,39]; (v) the results of cyanide poisoning and hot sulfuric acid leaching for Fe–N/C-800 suggested that ORR was primarily due to iron-free active sites that arose most likely from nitrogen doping [40]. The latter indicates that the metal can act as a carrier for selective incorporation of nitrogen motifs promoting the activity of adjacent carbon atoms of the support [41–44]. In recent years, the attention of the researchers was focused on iron carbides encapsulated into nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (FexC@NCNTs) demonstrating excellent ORR activity due to the local structure distortion caused by the metal species, which in turn leads to the strain effect on nitrogen-doped CNTs [45–48]. For example, in alkaline condition, the optimized FexC@NCNTs catalyst exhibits 0.98 V onset and 0.85 V half-wave potentials (vs RHE) or 0.82 and 0.68 V in acidic medium, respectively, along with good stability and methanol tolerance in both media [46]. To better understand the processes in the fuel cells, different models in comparison to a huge massive of experimental data and numerical algorithms were successfully employed for the rational design of fuel cells [49,50]. As stressed in review [51] and exemplified on Mo(W)-doped bismuth vanadate systems [52], specific surface chemistry has usually been neglected despite its pivotal influence on the catalytic activity; vacancies and/or dopants can induce changes in the electronic structure of the catalyst, tuning the activity of different catalytic sites. In a pioneering work devoted to the study of the kinetics and thermodynamics of the associative mechanism of ORR on the Fe–N4/Gr catalyst with the use of quantum-chemical calculations, the reaction was analyzed on Fe-doped, pyrrolic nitrogen-decorated graphene [53]. Due to the pyrrolic nature of nitrogens in the model structure and, hence, a higher size of the hole for metal helating, as compared to that formed by pyridinic nitrogens, the graphene sheet is significantly distorted from planarity. The reduction of HO* to H2O (* denotes adsorbed species) on this catalyst has the highest activation barrier (1.02 eV) on active metal center and overpotential η of 0.81 V, making it not only the rate-determining step (RDS) but also potential-determining step (PDS) in the four-electron ORR. The latter value is significantly overestimated with respect to the experiment (ηexp = 1.23 − Uonset , 0.39±0.05 V) [54,55]. Thermodynamically more stable structure having pyridinic nitrogen atoms in the Fe–N4/Gr fragment demonstrates a substantially lower activation barrier of the RDS of only 0.62 eV corresponding to O2* → HOO* transformation [56]. The free energy (ΔG) profile for ORR therein was not calculated neither in [56] nor in a later report by Aouama et al. [57]. The closest to the experiment η values were obtained by Wang et al. (0.47 V) [58] and Qin et al. (0.43 V) [59] by enabling, respectively, implicit and explicit solvation models in the calculations. Fe,N-doped carbon nanotubes, Fe–N4/CNT, show improved ORR activity compared with their graphene analogues and Pt/C catalysts due to outstanding physical, chemical and structural properties of CNTs [12,14,60-63]. It should be noted that CNTs are divided into (n,0)-zigzag, (n,n)-armchair and (n,m)-chiral (n and m are natural numbers, n ≠ m) different not only in the orientation of the benzene rings with respect to the axis of the nanotube but also in the electronic structure [64–67]. The latter has a strong effect on the catalytic properties of the nanotube-based materials, that creates additional difficulties in choosing proper nanocarbon support due to the challenge in selective growth of suitable CNT edges. Yoon et al. studied both graphitic (Ng) and pyridinic (Np) nitrogen doped, iron-codoped (10,0)-zigzag CNT catalysts and showed the possibility of outstanding ORR activity of Fe–Np/CNT due to the absence of band-gap energy (metallic or semi-metallic character of the catalyst), high binding energy of Fe and Np, lower work function, and magnetic moment [68]. Studying the Fe–N4/(10,0)-zigzag CNT, Gao et al. showed that the initially adsorbed O2 molecule can be subsequently reduced via the direct pathway on FeN4 site without any activation energy barrier [69]. On the example of armchair CNT supports of different length and diameter in the Fe–N4/CNT catalyst, Chen et al. demonstrated that the stability of active metal center is enhanced with the diameter of the tube, but reduced with its shortening, while the adsorption of reduced oxygen species weakens with the increase of the tube diameter [70]. In spite of substantial progress in the experimental and theoretical investigation of Fe–N4/NCM catalysts for ORR, especially those in which NCM is graphene, FeN4-doped carbon nanotubes remain less studied from the point of view of the effect of the zigzag or armchair structure of CNT on the ORR performance and stability. Moreover, two different orientations of FeN4 moiety along the axis of symmetry of CNT could be imagined. The question remains open as to how poisoning affects the FeN4 active site and why the activity of the catalyst only slightly decreases [41]. In this paper, we address our attention to the structure-reactivity relationship and the secondary ORR activity of the lattice carbon atoms [42–44] as a result of CO poisoning of FeN4 center incorporated in armchair or zigzag CNTs as a support with differently oriented FeN4 fragments as well as in graphene to solve these issues. Computational details All calculations were performed using the localized basis functions-based ORCA 5.0 suite of programs using spin unrestricted Kohn-Sham density functional theory (KS-DFT) calculations of the finite model systems [71]. The latter were found to perform as periodic models for localized properties or reactions, in particular, to compute reliable Gibbs free energies of the reaction in aqueous environment for the reduction or oxidation steps [72]. On the basis of general recommendations [73], the geometry optimization was performed using Grimme's DFT-D3(BJ) corrected revised version of GGA functional proposed by Perdew, Burke and Ernzerhof (revPBE-D3) [74] and balanced split valence double-ξ Def2-SVP basis set. Numerical second order derivatives of the energy with respect to the Cartesian nuclear coordinates were employed to assess thermochemical corrections. In order to obtain accurate total energies, a hybrid version of the functional, namely revPBE0-D3 and balanced split valence triple-ξ Def2-TZVP basis set, single point energy refinement was performed on the optimized geometry [75]. The Weigend Def2/J “universal” Coulomb fitting basis set, tight SCF convergence threshold were applied at all calculation steps. For structure visualization, ChemCraft 1.8 was employed [76]. Charge model 5 (CM5) charges proposed by Truhlar et al. [77], charge density difference (CDD), condensed Fukui indices and Mayer bond order analysis were performed using Multiwfn 3.8 [78]. Solvation effect on the mechanism was performed for water, using the conductor-like polarizable continuum model (C-PCM) throughout the manuscript. To assess the charge injection ability, the HOMO/LUMO (highest occupied molecular orbital/lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) energy gap (E gap) and vertical electron affinity (AEv) were used [79]. (1) E g a p = E L U M O − E H O M O (2) A E v = E N − E N + 1 where E N and E N+1 are the total energies of the N and N-+-1 electron systems corresponding to the addition of electron to the catalyst Cat + e – → Cat–•. The adsorption energy (E ads) characterizing the stability of the reduced oxygen-containing adsorbates on the catalyst active center was estimated by Eq. (3): (3) E ads = E adso rbate * cata lyst − E adso rbate − E cata lyst where E adsorbate*catalyst, E adsorbate, and E catalyst are total energies of the species adsorbed on the catalyst, the isolated adsorbate, and the model catalyst, respectively. E ads are negative for exothermic adsorption. The two- (2e) and four-electron (4e) ORR mechanisms (Fig. 1 ) were investigated in both acidic and alkaline media. The free energy diagrams for ORR pathways as a function of the electrode potential U, ΔG = f(U), were plotted in accordance with the Nørskov equation [80] Eq. (4): (4) Δ G = E ads + Δ ZPVE − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G pH where ΔZPVE and ΔS are the zero-point vibrational energy correction and entropy correction; T is the temperature (298.15 K); ΔGU = –neU, where n, e and U designate the number of electrons in the reaction, the electron charge and the electrode potential with respect to RHE, respectively; ΔG pH = kB T ln10 × pH, where kB is the Boltzmann constant. In this study, pH = 0 (ΔG pH = 0 eV) and pH = 13 (ΔG pH = 0.77 eV) were assumed for the acid and alkaline media, respectively. The total energy and entropy of H2O molecule were calculated at a pressure of 0.035 bar (the equilibrium vapor pressure of H2O at 298.15 K). The free energy of O2 was estimated according to the reaction O2 + 4[H + + e –] = 2H2O, ΔG of which is –4.92 eV, and the free energy of H2O2 was taken from the reaction O2 + 2[H + + e –] = H2O2, ΔG = –1.39 eV. The free energy of [H + + e –] was estimated as half of the energy of H2 molecule in accordance with computational hydrogen electrode model [81]. The empirical vibrational frequencies and entropies of molecules were taken from the NIST database [82]. The ZPVE and entropy corrections to the total energies of the adsorbates on the active center of model catalysts were taken from the calculations. In order to analyze the efficiency of the active center of the catalyst for ORR and to determine the PDS on it, the overpotential η ORR [73] at U = 0 in acidic medium was calculated using Eq. (5): (5) η ORR = 1.23 − Δ Δ G min / e where 1.23 is the thermodynamic potential of the reaction O2 + 4[H + + e –] = 2H2O in volts; ΔΔGmin is the free energy change for the slowest elementary step as a result of single [H + + e –] transfer; e is the electron charge [27]. Results and discussion Model structures Earlier, it has been shown that the adsorption energy E ads of reduced oxygen species substantially increases with narrowing the diameter of the nanotube in Fe–N4/(n,0)-CNT to less than 5–7 nm, that may result in irreversible oxidation, whereas the increase of diameter to more than 8 nm increases the stability of the catalyst [70]. With this in mind, we have chosen as carbon supports the single-walled (6,6)-armchair and (12,0)-zigzag CNTs, of 8.4 and 9.5 nm diameter, respectively. Initial length of the model CNTs was >20 nm. Two adjacent carbon atoms equidistant from the ends of the nanotube were removed from the structure to form a divacancy defect. The iron atom was placed in the formed hole, and the adjacent carbon atoms were replaced by pyridinic nitrogen atoms. Further, the outer belts of carbons were cut off in such a manner that only two belts of carbons distant from the nitrogen atom closest to the end of the nanotube of the FeN4 moiety remained. The coordinates of the outer carbons at both ends of the nanotube were fixed accordingly to prevent model Fe–N4/CNT unit distortion. The thus constructed Fe–N4/(6,6)- and Fe–N4/(12,0)-CNTs with two different orientations (parallel and skew) of the FeN4 moiety along the axis of symmetry of the CNT are depicted in Fig. 2 . As the graphene model, the molecule of pyrene with four additional carbon belts was taken and optimized, two of which were finally removed, and the coordinates of carbon atoms of the formed outer carbon belt were fixed and the FeN4 motif was inserted as described above. Note that the content of iron in all structures is very low varying from 0.66 to 0.91 at.% Fe (see Table S1 for Fe/C/N ratio) and, thus, matching requirement (iv) proposed by Liu et al. [12]. Analysis of reactivity Structural parameters of all catalysts as well as CM5 atomic charges and Mayer bond orders are summarized in Table S1. The Fe–N bond lengths increase in the following order of the FeN4-doped model NCMs: CNTa1 < CNTz2 ≈ Gr < CNTa2 < CNTz1 from 1.88 to 1.96 Å, whereas the bond order (and hence the structure stability) slightly increases in the order CNTz1 < Gr ≈ CNTa2 < CNTz2 ≈ CNTa1 from 0.66 to 0.69. The higher the bond order, the more electrons are shared between the atoms in the Fe–N bond, and the higher is the stability of the catalyst [83,84]. This is in good agreement with atomic charges on Fe atom increasing in the same order from +0.71 to +0.80, Table 1 . In view of non-symmetric arrangement of nitrogens in the FeN4 motif with respect to the axis of the nanotube in Fe–N4/CNTa2 and Fe–N4/CNTz2, these structures are characterized by a small Jahn–Teller effect resulting in a slight (by 0.02 Å) shortening of the distances between the iron and nitrogen atoms forming the plane at the lowest angle to the axis of symmetry of CNT. The effect is significantly increased for HO2* and HO* adsorbates. Very recently it was shown that the Jahn–Teller distortion can promote electrocatalytic reactions, in particular, the photocatalytic Haber-Bosch process [85]. The charges on the nitrogen atoms N1–N4 and carbon atoms C1–C2, the latter forming the >C1=C2< fragment (С2 active site) [42–44] directly attached to FeN4 motif, practically do not change in going from one model structure to another being ca. –0.40 (N) and +0.10 (C), respectively. The distance between the carbon atoms С1 and С2 of the С2 site varies in a narrow range from 1.42 Å (Fe–N4/CNTa1) to 1.45 Å (Fe–N4/CNTz1), whereas the bond order for the FeN4-doped model NCMs increases in the order Gr < CNTz1 ≈ CNTa2 < CNTz2 << CNTa1 from 1.08 to 1.34. Looking ahead, it is worth noting that the increase of the bond order between С1 and С2 atoms of the С2 site, and hence the enhanced π-character of bonding, promotes catalytic activity of the lattice carbons for ORR only in the case of the latter structure, Fe–N4/CNTa1. The energy and distribution of frontier molecular orbitals in the catalyst, responsible for the nucleophilic (HOMO) and electrophilic (LUMO) parts of the molecule are important in Marcus theory of electron transfer, especially for the kinetics and hence chemical reactivity [79]. As follows from the distribution of frontier molecular orbitals, Figs. S1 and S2, both HOMO and LUMO are mainly localized on the carbon atoms of the NCM, with only a small fraction of HOMO being localized on the iron atom, and the contribution of LUMO is even lower. Taking into account a positive charge of the chelated metal ion, the ORR on FeN4/NCM catalysts is charge controlled rather than orbital controlled reaction. According to Janak's theorem [86], the LUMO energy and hence the electron affinity of the catalyst, EAv, is crucial for ORR in the stage of initial adsorption of such nucleophile as dioxygen, Table 1, due to the tendency to attack sites of relatively low electron density, like metals in MNx/NCM. Thus, EAv for FeN4-doped model NCMs increase in the order CNTz2 < CNTz1 < Gr < CNTa1 < CNTa2 from 3.65 to 4.96 eV, indicating poorer electron-withdrawing properties of FeN4-doped zigzag CNTs as compared to their armchair analogues, and graphene is in between the two. As a result, charge density distribution (CDD) plots, for FeN4-doped armchair CNTs and graphene Fig. S3, demonstrate a pronounced accumulation of charge density on the iron atom in the inward direction perpendicular to the plane of FeN4 fragment, while the FeN4-doped zigzag CNTs exhibits small CDD changes on the metal atom. Another characteristics responsible for the ease of the electron transfer in the catalyst from HOMO to LUMO, E gap, decreases in the order Gr >> CNTa1 > CNTz1 > CNTz2 ≈ CNTa2 from 1.93 to 1.04 eV. The lower E gap, the easier the electron migrates from one orbital to another [87]. For adsorption of triplet dioxygen (biradical) this results in a higher stability of the formed O2* adsorbate. The same reasoning is applicable to other reduced radical species involved in ORR, like HO•, HOO•, O•, each of which triggers its own sequence of transformations in ORR. Finally, the Fe–N4/Gr model catalyst is non-polar as it has zero resultant dipole moment, while the armchair CNT supported FeN4 is slightly polar irrespective of the latter orientation in the CNT, Table 1. In case of zigzag CNT as a support, the dipole moment is larger, increasing in going from the parallel to the skewed FeN4 motif. The dipole moment of all analyzed Fe–N4/CNT catalysts is oriented almost perpendicularly from FeN4 moiety to the symmetry axis of the nanotube. Adsorption energies of ORR intermediates As the first elementary step of the ORR, the adsorption of dioxygen molecule on the active catalyst center may result in three possible types of dioxygen-containing adsorbates, O2*, namely Griffith side-on adsorption of both oxygen atoms of O2 on one surface atom, O*O*; Pauling end-on adsorption of one of two oxygen atoms, OO*; and Yeager side-on bridge adsorption between two surface atoms, *OO* intermediate, Fig. S4 [88]. The formation of the first two types of adsorbates with participation of MNx/NCM catalysts is typical for metal centers, while the Yeager-type adsorbate *OO* can be formed only with participation of the carbon atoms of the NCM support [42–44]. Adsorption energies E ads of oxygen molecule on the iron active center of Fe–N4/NCM, as a result of the formation of Pauling-type OO* adsorbate, are more exothermic (0.48÷0.76 eV) compared with Griffith side-on isomer, Table 2 . The exception is Fe–N4/CNTz1 model catalyst, for which the reverse behavior is observed and the end-on O2 adsorption is slightly endothermic. In case of metal center of Fe–N4/CNTz2 catalyst, the O*O* and OO* isomers are equivalent in terms of E ads. The increase of exothermicity of formation of the Pauling-type OO* adsorbate on the metal center in the series of model Fe–N4/NCM catalysts nicely correlates with the radical attack susceptibility of Fe atom, f Fe 0 (r = 0.904, n = 5, s 0 = 0.02) and satisfactorily with the positive charge on the iron atom (r = 0.844, n = 5, s 0 = 0.04), that proves the assumption of the charge control of ORR. At the same time, the formation of Yeager-type *OO* adsorbate on C2 site of Fe–N4/NCM is exothermic only in the case of CNTa1 and CNTz2 as supports, while on the graphene support its formation is strongly endothermic. This is in good agreement with the reduced π-bonding between the С1 and С2 atoms of the С2 site of Fe–N4/Gr as proposed above. To the best of our knowledge, the activity of the С2 site of Fe–N4/NCM catalyst in ORR has not been previously considered, so this is the first report on this topic. Recently, on the example of M–N4/CNT, where M = V, Nb, Ti, Zr, we have shown that O2* adsorbate can suffer the O–O bond cleavage to form more stable dioxo 2O** species on the metal center (or diepoxy intermediate on the C2 site) via the low-lying transition state resulting in much more exothermic adsorption of molecular oxygen [43,44]. As follows from Table 2, this is true only for metal center of Fe–N4/CNTz1 and C2 site of Fe–N4/NCM, where NCM is CNTa2, CNTz, or Gr except CNTa1. Theoretical study of the kinetics of O2* → 2O** dissociation has shown a high activation barrier (E a = 1.19 eV) for such a reaction to occur on the metal center of Fe–N4/Gr [89]. Another important intermediate, whose energy of adsorption E ads characterizes the tolerance of the catalyst to poisoning, is carbon monooxide, CO. It can be formed by partial oxidation of the carbon support of the catalyst [90] and acts as catalytic poison for FeNx-containing metal organic frameworks. However, it was shown that introduction of CO into the cathode space of the Fe–Nx/Gr catalyst results only in a slight decrease of the catalytic activity in ORR, that can be due to the presence of non-metal catalytically active centers [41], or due to reversibility of the *CO adsorbate formation. In order to answer this question, we considered the structures formed by adsorption of either one or two CO molecules, Table 2. In the case of graphene and armchair CNT supported FeN4, adsorption of one CO molecule on the metal center is only ca. 0.1 eV exothermic compared to that of Pauling-type dioxygen OO* adsorbate, and the equilibrium is ca. 0.2 eV shifted to the formation of *CO adsorbate, see Table S2 for free energies. Surprisingly, the adsorption of CO on metal center of both zigzag CNT supported FeN4 motifs is endothermic by 0.06 (z1) and 0.62 eV (z2) compared to that of O2. Close analysis of charge variation on the iron atom (Δq < 0) and Mayer bond order of Fe–С in *CO adsorbates for all Fe–N4/NCMs, Table S3, revealed the predominance of σ-bonding rather than π-backbonding as a result of CO lone pair donation to the metal [91]. The values of the correlation coefficients for Fukui electrophilicity, f Fe – (r = 0.991, n = 5, s 0 = 0.07), and nucleophilicity, f Fe + (r = 0.329, n = 5, s 0 = 0.04), indices as the function of E ads for *CO adsorbates, Table 1, confirm this conclusion. In this case the catalyst acts as an electrophile and the endothermicity of the *CO adsorbate formation on FeN4 incorporated in zigzag CNT can be explained by poor electron-acceptor properties of the metal. Carbon atoms of the C2 site in the N-doped NCMs are inert to CO adsorption [41]. The adsorption of the second CO molecule on the iron atom of the *CO adsorbate can occur on the same side where the first CO molecule was adsorbed (double top configuration) or on the opposite side (inner side in case of CNT). The former configuration was found to be less stable than the 2(*CO) adsorbate of the opposite configuration not only in terms of E ads but also in free energy ΔG, Tables 2 and S2, and hence was excluded from further consideration. Although the formation of 2(*CO) is more exothermic than of *CO, the free energy gain of adsorption of the second CO molecule is more than four times as low as that of the first one for Fe–N4/CNTa1 (22 %) and 1.75 times less for Fe–N4/Gr model catalysts (5 %). On Fe–N4/CNTa2, the situation is different: the adsorption of the first CO molecule is exergonic by 0.2 eV, whereas that of the second CO molecule is endergonic by 0.08 eV, Table S2. Therefore, the iron active centers of the armchair CNTa as well as graphene supported FeN4 moieties are prone to irreversible poisoning by adsorption of one or two CO molecules, making it impossible for ORR to occur further on the metal center of the catalysts. As distinct from Fe–N4/CNTa and Fe–N4/Gr, the interaction of CO with the zigzag catalyst Fe–N4/CNTz is endergonic and hence unlikely. This allows to assume that the ORR on this catalyst should be tolerant to the presence of CO. The adsorption energy and relative stability of the third important intermediate of ORR, namely, the HO2* adsorbate, determines further course of the reaction on a specific active center of the catalyst towards the reaction product H2O2 or H2O (2e or 4e ORR pathway, respectively). If the oxohydroxy O*HO* intermediate formed by the O–O bond rupture in HO2* is more stable than the peroxy HOO* intermediate, the dissociative route of ORR can become preferred over the associative one on the way to the first of two possible molecules of H2O, thus excluding the formation of hydrogen peroxide H2O2 as less energetically favorable co-product. The orientation of the FeN4 moiety along the nanotube axis affects the stability of HO2* adsorbates not only on metal center but also on C2 site. Thus, only in the case of armchair Fe–N4/CNTs and the skewed FeN4 in the zigzag Fe–N4/CNTz2, the HO2* adsorbate is more prone to adsorption on the C2 site in the oxohydroxy O*HO* form, Table 2. Moreover, the same adsorbate is more readily formed on the metal center of the parallel-oriented FeN4 in the zigzag Fe–N4/CNTz1 as compared to the peroxy HOO* adsorbate. At this point the ORR may shift from metal to the C2 site of the armchair CNT supported FeN4 as well as on the skewed FeN4 of the zigzag Fe–N4/CNTz2 following the dissociative ORR pathway. The same pathway is predicted on the metal center of the parallel-oriented zigzag Fe–N4/CNTz1 catalyst, whereas the associative one occurs on the same site of Fe–N4/Gr [56]. The stability of epoxyhydroxy O**HO* adsorbate on the C2 site of Fe–N4/CNT model catalysts was also considered, but they were found to be less stable than their oxohydroxy O*HO* isomers. Further reduction of HO2* adsorbates may result in the formation of hydrogen peroxide H2O2*, oxo O* or dihydroxy HO*HO* adsorbates. The adsorption of H2O2 is slightly exothermic on the iron center of the skewed FeN4 doped armchair CNT and graphene, whereas on the metal center of the zigzag CNT it is endothermic, Table 2. The geometry optimization of H2O2* adsorbate on the metal center of Fe–N4/CNTa1 resulted in spontaneous O–O bond rupture and formation of HO*HO* adsorbate. Both H2O2* and HO*HO* intermediates adsorbed on the metal center are less stable than the oxo O* adsorbate. The adsorption energy E ads of the latter is almost equal to that on all Fe–N4/NCM model catalysts and amounts to ca. –5.7 eV. In case of the C2 site, oxo O* intermediate is more favorable for skewed FeN4 incorporated in the zigzag CNT, whereas epoxy O** adsorbate is predicted for other CNT-based catalysts. This may indicate the preference of 4e-ORR with the formation of H2O over the two-electron H2O2 by-product on both iron and C2 centers. The adsorption energy E ads of HO* intermediate on the metal center is somewhat higher than that on the C2 site and equals to ca. –2.2 eV irrespective of the nature of the NCM support, Table 2. At the same time, the latter affects the E ads of HO adsorption on the C2 site, so that the exothermicity on different supports increases in the order CNTz2 < Gr < CNTz1 < CNTa2 << CNTa1 from 1.30 to 2.11 eV. Finally, the reduction of HO* adsorbate leads to the formation of water H2O* adsorbate. The adsorption of H2O on metal center of model catalysts is as low as ca. 0.34 eV exothermic, while in case of Fe–N4/CNTz1 it is 0.45 eV endothermic. The comparison of adsorption energies (E ads) and free energies (ΔG) of the OO* and H2O* adsorbates indicates possible easy regeneration of the metal center (H2O desorption/O2 adsorption) for all considered Fe–N4/NCM catalysts, Table 2 and S2. The electrode potential effect and the ORR mechanism In order to determine the nature of PDS and the overpotential η ORR for active centers of Fe–N4/NCM model catalysts, the free energy diagrams were constructed using the most stable ORR species in both acidic and alkaline media. As follows from Fig. 3 , ORR on metal center of the parallel-oriented FeN4 moiety incorporated in the armchair CNT or graphene follows conventional associative mechanism due to the more exergonic formation of HOO* adsorbate as compared to that of its O*HO* isomer. The comparison of free energies of O* (or HO*HO* in case of Fe–N4/CNTz2) of the adsorbate and the product of 2e-ORR, namely H2O2 + *, demonstrates the predominance of 4e-pathway on the metal center for all catalysts, irrespective of the support. Moreover, the ORR is reversible for all model catalysts as compared to oxophilic transition metals in MN4 fragment capable of stable reduced oxygen species formation regardless of the electrode potential [43,44]. The PDS for the ORR on all CNT-supported FeN4 moieties is associated with the fourth [H + + e– ] transfer, namely HO* → (H2O* →) * + H2O reduction, while * + O2 → (OO* →) HOO* is the RDS on Fe–N4/Gr. Due to instability of H2O* adsorbate and fast H2O release with regeneration of the catalyst active center, its effect on the thermochemistry of ORR, such as η ORR, is usually ignored. Thus, the efficiency of the metal center in different NCM supported model catalysts for ORR is increased in the order CNTz1 < Gr ≈ CNTz2 ≈ CNTa1 << CNTa2, the corresponding η ORR values for PDS are given in Table 3 . This allows to predict the metal center of the skewed FeN4 motif incorporated in the armchair nanotube as most efficient, with the free energy profile being close to that of an ideal ORR catalyst among other NCM supports. The parallel-oriented FeN4 motif of the zigzag, Fe–N4/CNTz1, was found to be the least efficient. Moreover, its activity is suffered from endergonic adsorption of dioxygen molecule, leading to overall retardation of ORR, Fig. 4(c). As follows from Figs. S5–S7 and Table 3, the same is true for C2 site of all Fe–N4/NCMs, the endoergicity being increased in the order of supports CNTa1 < CNTz2 < CNTz1 < CNTa2 << Gr from 0.47 to 1.75 eV. Hence, the occurrence of ORR on the C2 site of Fe–N4/Gr is strictly prohibited. Despite the endoergicity of O2 adsorption on the C2 site of Fe–N4/CNTa1 and Fe–N4/CNTz1, DFT calculations predict a lower overpotential, η ORR, equal to 0.40 and 0.20 V, as compared to that on the metal center of the catalyst (0.52 and 0.57 V, respectively). Application of the Eyring equation to the rate of O2* adsorbate formation using the free energy of oxygen adsorption on the C2 site predicts the rates of ca. 3.0 × 104 and 6.5 s–1 at 298 K. Thus, until the overpotential corresponding to the metal center is reached, the active center is the C2 site of the parallel-oriented FeN4 incorporated in both armchair and zigzag CNTs while the metal center of non-poisoned catalysts Fe–N4/NCM is predicted to be most active for ORR compared to the C2 site. Figs. S5–S8 represent ORR thermodynamics on active centers of model catalysts at different electrode potentials U in an alkaline medium where no significant changes are observed compared to an acidic medium. Since the metal center of armchair CNT and graphene supported FeN4 motifs can be easily deactivated by irreversible CO adsorption, we have considered the possibility of participation of C2 site of the poisoned catalyst for ORR using Fe(CO)–N4/CNTa and the most stable Fe(CO)2–N4/Gr as model catalysts. The adsorption energies E ads and free energies ΔG for possible ORR intermediates on these catalysts are summarized in Table 4 . The adsorption of dioxygen molecule O2 on C2 site of iron-poisoned armchair CNT catalysts is slightly exothermic. However, on graphene it is not only endothermic but also highly endergonic, so that C2 site of Fe(CO)2–N4/Gr model catalyst cannot participate in ORR. For this reason, the free energy profiles for ORR on C2 site were prepared only for Fe(CO)–N4/CNTa model catalysts, Fig. 4 , S9. As follows from Fig. 4, on both C2 sites the adsorption of oxygen is endergonic, the calculated rates of O2* formation being 1.0 × 102 and 3 s–1 for parallel and skewed FeN4 motifs incorporated in armchair CNT, respectively. Nevertheless, the ORR follows dissociative pathway and O** → HO* (or HO*HO* → HO* for Fe(CO)–N4/CNTa2) transformations are predicted as PDS steps, η ORR being 0.71 and 0.49 V. Thus, the activity of C2 site of Fe(CO)–N4/CNTa1 is lower than that of its non-poisoned predecessor, while the C2 site of Fe(CO)–N4/CNTa2 can show enhanced ORR activity, the overall rate being limited by adsorption of molecular oxygen. Conclusion In summary, the ORR performance and stability of the Fe,N-doped armchair and zigzag carbon nanotubes with differently oriented FeN4 moiety as well as graphene were studied theoretically. The calculations showed that the nature of the support and the orientation of the MN4 motif not only determine the electronic structure of the catalyst but strongly affect the catalytic activity and thermodynamics of ORR. Thus, the carbon atoms forming the vinylic fragment at FeN4 in the nanotubes, unlike in graphene, can act as the C2 catalytic site in the ORR, on par with the metal or even exceed it in the value of starting potential due to the enhanced π-character of bonding but be inferior to it due to endoergicity of adsorption of dioxygen molecule. ORR on the metal center of the parallel-oriented FeN4 incorporated in armchair CNT or in graphene follows conventional four-electron associative pathway and the dissociative one in case of other model systems. The nature of the potential-determining step for FeN4 doped CNT is related to the final protonation of HO* adsorbate, the release of the second molecule of water and regeneration of the active center, while on graphene it is the initial reduction of the adsorbed O2 molecule. Among other NCMs, the zigzag oriented nanotubes stand out by the ability to reversibly adsorb carbon monoxide on the metal due to low electrophilicity of the latter on these supports. In contrast, the FeN4-doped graphene is irreversibly poisoned and becomes inactive for ORR. The FeN4-doped armchair CNTs remain active after the metal poisoning due to the carbon atoms of the support, although the process is limited by O2 adsorption. Briefly: • The ORR on Fe,N-doped CNMs is charge controlled and strongly dependent on the nature of the support and the orientation of the MN4 motif; • Iron atom in FeN4-doped zigzag CNTs is less electrophilic and less subjected to CO-poisoning than in their armchair analogues and graphene; • Carbon atoms at FeN4 form catalytically active C2 site in nanotubes but not in graphene; • The catalytic activity of C2 site is on par with the metal or may even exceed it; • The 4e-mechanism prevails over the 2e-mechanism and may occur either in associative or dissociative way; • The potential-determining step on metal center of CNT supported FeN4 motif is protonation of HO* adsorbate, while on graphene it is the reduction of O2* adsorbate. coredata.dc:description: Theoretical calculations at the revPBE0-D3(PCM)/def2-TZVP level were performed to investigate the mechanism of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) on the FeN4-doped NCMs (graphene, single-walled (6,6)-armchair and (12,0)-zigzag carbon nanotubes) as catalysts. The effect of the support and relative orientation of FeN4 fragment in the catalyst structure on the ORR activity and stability of the differently adsorbed successive intermediates (O2*, HO2*, O*, HO*, H2O2*, H2O*) is discussed. Special attention is given to the possible poisoning effect of CO. The relative catalytic activity of the metal center and the adjacent C2 site of the carbon support are analyzed depending on the structure of the support. The metal catalytic center on the armchair nanotube and graphene supports is prone to deactivation by poisoning with CO, whereas in the zigzag nanotube supported catalyst the metal center is tolerant to CO. The four-electron mechanism of ORR is shown to be preferable over the two-electron mechanism in both acidic and alkaline media, both on the metal and C2 centers.
coredata.dc:title: Oxygen Electroreduction Reaction on Iron, Nitrogen-doped Nanocarbons: Structure – Reactivity Relationship
